This bug is a critical one: the workbench seems to open/restore editors in the
shutdown phase (QuitAction.run).
This is probably an M4 candidate.  MVM?

Hmm...

Looks like there's several independent bugs at work here.

1. All the editors are being loaded at shutdown (dupe of bug 75440, a major bug
belonging to workbench).

2. One of the editors is throwing an exception on initialization with the
message string "The classfile is not on the classpath". I suspect this was
thrown on line 625 of ClassFileEditor.java, and it looks like it may be normal
behavior for an editor which is restored on an input that no longer exists. If
so, then the bug here is that a normal and expected condition is generating
exceptions that get written the error log. Minor bug belonging to JDT UI.

3. AbstractTestEditor is repackaging initialization exceptions in a manner that
obscures the original stack trace (making it hard to determine the exact cause
of 2). Minor bug belonging to Text.

4. The presentation for an EditorStack is still being notified of changes after
its widget is disposed. It is likely that this only occurs when an exception is
thrown during shutdown, but it is still a bug.

Created an attachment (id=16618)
Workspace demonstrating the bug

Created an attachment (id=16620)
Patch for issue #3

This patch fixes the stack trace for init exceptions in AbstractTextEditor

More info on issue #4:

This is occurring because the EditorStack is being disposed inside its
setSelection method. This is triggered by
EditorManager$Editor.getEditor(boolean) line: 1487. When an editor throws an
exception during initialization, the editormanager tries to forcably remove it
from the layout by calling page.closeEditor. It should be creating an error part
instead. Here's the relevant stack trace:

	CTabFolder(Widget).dispose() line: 375
	TabbedStackPresentation.dispose() line: 257
	PartStack$1(DefaultStackPresentationSite).dispose() line: 82
	EditorStack(PartStack).dispose() line: 580
	EditorSashContainer.removeEditor(EditorPane) line: 218
	EditorAreaHelper.closeEditor(EditorPane) line: 122
	EditorAreaHelper.closeEditor(IEditorReference) line: 100
	EditorManager.closeEditor(IEditorReference) line: 225
	WorkbenchPage.closeEditor(IEditorReference, boolean) line: 963
	EditorManager$Editor.getEditor(boolean) line: 1487
	EditorManager$Editor.getPart(boolean) line: 1474
	EditorPane(PartPane).setVisible(boolean) line: 329
	PresentablePart.setVisible(boolean) line: 126
	PresentablePartFolder.select(IPresentablePart) line: 266
	LeftToRightTabOrder.select(IPresentablePart) line: 65
	TabbedStackPresentation.selectPart(IPresentablePart) line: 381
	EditorStack(PartStack).refreshPresentationSelection() line: 1047
	EditorStack(PartStack).setSelection(LayoutPart) line: 1011
	EditorStack(PartStack).updateContainerVisibleTab() line: 1247
	EditorStack(PartStack).remove(LayoutPart) line: 764
	EditorSashContainer.removeEditor(EditorPane) line: 213
	EditorAreaHelper.closeEditor(EditorPane) line: 122
	EditorAreaHelper.closeEditor(IEditorPart) line: 111
	EditorManager.closeEditor(IEditorReference) line: 221
	WorkbenchPage.closeEditors(IEditorReference[], boolean) line: 938
	WorkbenchPage.closeAllEditors(boolean) line: 881
	WorkbenchPage.dispose() line: 1237

Since this only happens if another exception is thrown during initialization, it
does not need to be fixed for M4 (although it should really be fixed for 3.1).

Issue 1 is a dupe, and the remaining issues aren't critical for M4. Reducing
priority and tagging for M5.

Re comment 6 (patch for item 3) in text land: I see the benefit of the patch but
I don't see the benefit of unpacking the status at i.e. we could use the
CoreException in all cases instead of unpacking and using its status in some of
the cases (where IStatus.getException() != null), right?

I filed a new bug 81057 for this.

Sadly, using CoreException in all cases would be just as bad, since this would
lose the stack trace in situations where the the real cause was attached to the
CoreException (which appears to be the intended usage).

From what I can tell, there's two ways to use CoreException:

1. A CoreException wraps the real exception. In this case, it has an IStatus
whose message is a translated NLS string for the error, and whose getException()
will contain an Exception whose stack trace and non-translated English text will
be logged. Note that only one level of nesting is possible. No matter how many
times a CoreException is repackaged, the outermost getException needs to point
to the most specific exception.

2. A CoreException IS the real exception. In this case, it has an IStatus
containing a (possibly) untranslated English string to be logged and its
getException() is null.

It appears that usage 1 was the intended use of CoreException, and the Eclipse
error log assumes that any exception it gets is in this form. However, lots of
code throws CoreExceptions of form 2 since they're easier to construct.

This means that anyone who wants to repackage a CoreException needs to check
what type it is. A type 1 CoreException cannot be wrapped inside another
CoreException and the nested getException() must be preserved. A type 2
CoreException must be preserved, but it can be wrapped inside another CoreException.

...if this makes any sense at all...

>Sadly, using CoreException in all cases would be just as bad...
Yes and no. Yes, because that's the way PartInitException(String, Throwable)
currently handles this and no, because I pass all (even more) information to
PartInitException which then decides not to look into a CoreException (which it
could). Anyway, I'll apply the patch as is after M4.

PartInitException isn't supposed to look into a CoreException it is given in its
constructor. The exception you give it in its constructor will be the exception
whose stack trace is logged. Right or wrong, PartInitException is a type of
CoreException and that's how all CoreExceptions work.

Try logging the following exceptions and see what you get:

// Two exceptions to log
Throwable a = new Exception("blah blah blah");
CoreException b = new CoreException(new Status(Status.ERROR, "bogusplugin", 
0, "hello world", null));

// Different ways of wrapping the exceptions
CoreException wrapper1 = new CoreException(new Status(Status.ERROR,
"bogusplugin", 0, "some error", a)); // Works
CoreException wrapper2 = new CoreException(new Status(Status.ERROR, 
"bogusplugin", 0, "some error", b)); // Works
CoreException wrapper3 = new CoreException(b.getStatus()); // Doesn't work

// Different ways of wrapping a wrapper
CoreException ww1 = new CoreException(wrapper1.getStatus()); // Works
CoreException ww2 = new CoreException(new Status(Status.ERROR,
"bogusplugin", 0, "some error", wrapper1.getStatus().getException())); // Works
CoreException ww3 = new CoreException(new Status(Status.ERROR,
"bogusplugin", 0, "some error", wrapper1)); // Doesn't work
Verified in I20050401-1205 using the attached workspace.
